text:
Ahh awesome! Yeah I found the best way to pick up Nuke was to dive in and play around. Finding out what nodes do when you plug them together. 

Here’s the link to the podcast: <https://www.podbean.com/podcast-detail/u249z-8de2a/The-Chernobyl-Podcast>

It’s more about the film making and storytelling than the VFX but still a good listen!

I’m terms of tips for roto. When I get a roto shot in I sit and watch it over and over again. Taking in all the edges I need to roto. I’ll then go and chat with whoever is going to be picking up the roto to comp the shot to make sure we are on the same page as to what needs doing. 

One of the main tips for roto is having good shape breakdown. By this I mean rather than trying to have 1 roto shape that does an entire edge, break it up into smaller shapes that are easier to follow. You want your shapes to stay consistent through out the movement of the shot. For my roto I tend to focus on one edge at a time. So say I have a shot of a character walking towards camera, I will watch the shot and check what needs to be done. Then I’ll go in and I’ll start on his arm, breaking down the shapes based on the edges I can see. I’ll get that looking nice and not boiling, then move on to the next part, that might be the other arm or a leg or whatever looks easiest. With shots I find that when I first pick them up I get a bit daunted by how much work there is. By doing the easy bits first it gets me in the rhythm of the shot and I may spot details I didn’t spot first time. 

Do you have Nuke Noncommercial at home? I can set up a script with an example if you like? 

Another tip is to always use bsplines rather than beziers. For good roto we don’t want to see the edges moving between each frame, this is called boiling. We want the edge to stay consistent and not move around too much. 

Another thing that is useful for roto is using trackers. I will often use a tracker to stabilise my shot. I do this so I can neutralise as much movement as possible and just focus on the edge I am working on. I will then Matchmove the roto I have done back and it will match the shot that is unstabilised. As always if this isn’t making sense I will set up an example script and show you what I mean. 

There are millions of other little tips and tricks but you tend to pick them up with experience. I found the best way to get better at roto is to just do it, by doing more shots you will work out what techniques work and which ones don’t. 

With LinkedIn, yeah sure I guess that would be ok! I don’t post a whole lot on there tho to be honest.
